summary: The text discusses the prophecy and eventual destruction of Jerusalem, which was foretold by the Lord and fulfilled by the Roman emperors Titus and Vespasian forty years after the Passion of Christ, during the same festival when Christ was crucified. The city was destroyed, and its people killed or sold into slavery. The passage suggests that this calamity came upon them because they did not recognize the time of their visitation and rejected Christ, their redeemer. The subversion of the city serves as a testament to this event, highlighting its spiritual significance and the consequences of ignoring divine judgment.
